text: I rush upstairs three steps at a time. The corridor is so cold it feels as if no one has lived here for years. Her door is slightly ajar, a thin sliver of light spilling through the crack.
“Who are you, really? How did you know the key was under the rug? Do you know me?”
From inside, her voice comes cold and sharp: “Don’t come in.”
“The more you ask, the more danger you’re in.”
She pushes the door open just a little. I can only see her standing in the shadows, her face pale, dark circles heavy beneath her eyes.
“Go downstairs. Take care of your wound.”
“At least tell me—why are you not doing anything?”
Her tone isn’t harsh, but it leaves no room for argument. It’s not a discussion—it’s an order.
“I’m staying here tonight. Don’t come up again.”
The door clicks shut. I stand in the corridor, the bruise on my face throbbing, my chest feeling even tighter.
I grit my teeth and turn to go downstairs. She pushed me away completely, as if afraid that one more word from me would cause trouble.
